12987572.review:
As far as visual novels go, this was one of the better ones; beautiful character design, numerous still shots that add to the story, a realistic main character and a twist ending that brought the whole game together. 

I approached the game with a grain of salt, after all, animals turning into people is a rather fantastical. I figured it would be  a slapstic piece worth a few laughs. Pleasently mistaken, Dandelion offered an deeper underlying story that brought a more tought provoking level to an already enjoyable game.  The idea of having all the pathways sewn together in an overlying story arch is refreshing to say the least.

The game has faults in its own right. In order to reach the ending on a given pathway, you have to repeditivly raise stats and keep your stress level down. One of the characters, in my opinion, becomes too possessive and dangerous without any option to counteract the behavior.

Other than that, a very enjoyable game. I spent many nights unable to pull away from my computer screen, wanting to see what happens next. If you like this, I highly suggest purchasing Cheritz's other game Nameless. They remove the leveling/stats aspect making the focus more on the story.

12909246.review:
Spoiler-free review based on four out of the five available routes - might be updated as more routes are played.

From a production point of view, Dandelion is phenomenal. The opening video is great and the song catchy. The art is consistent and delivers; I'm not crazy about the art style in itself, with funky legs and necks, but wow the bishonen was strong. The music used is okay. Few tracks stayed in my mind, but I always consider a non intrusive soundtrack a good thing. Voice acting is truly amazing!

There was no tutorial. There is no need for one, as I guess the only people who will play Dandelion are familiar with visual novels already, and there is a certain standard UI used in the genre. Nevertheless, I found out the player's inventory by accident. The location of it should have been mentioned, I think.

The statistics you need to raise are Art, Beauty and Femininity. Each love interest has different requirements that you need to meet in order to continue the relationship. Do activities to raise statistics. You will meet the love interests in the house, and have the possibility to interact with them to raise the relationship points. As you swirl around interacting with your boyfriend and practicing the housewife life, you also need to keep low Stress and Pressure. 

I saw a problem in the stats. In the writing as well, in certain routes. 
Heejung can only act within the walls of her house. Heejung has the function to save the male interest from his painful past. She is unaware of her feelings, unaware of her needs, incapable of relating personal experience to the same romantic clichés she criticizes when she reads Harlequin novels or goes to the movies. True, Heejung overcomes her fear, but she does not accomplishes it by herself. Her knight on a white horse does the talking to the source of her nightmares. She needs her prince to save her. (Notable exception is [spoiler]Jieun[/spoiler]'s route, which favorably impressed me!) Typical otoge MC that I can't identify with: despite the universal nature of her conflict, it's approached in such a childish way that it made me feel annoyed instead of empathetic.

Despite all this, I still recommend the game--it's Cheritz. Just beware the stat grind!

12825502.review:
**This review of Dandelion - Wishes brought to you - may contain minor spoilers.**

Dandelion - Wishes brought to you - is the debute otome game for the Korean video game studio, Cheritz. The game was released in South Korea in August 2012 and was released in the US in August 2012. The game was released on Steam  on September 29, 2014.

The game revolves around Heejung, a Korean college student majoring in business with a penchant for art. One day, she wakes up to discover a basket of animals in her room: two cats and three rabbits. Heejung eventually adopts the animals as her own, only to discover that the would-be animals actually have human forms. Moreover, they're actually from another world entirely. 

DISCLAIMER: While I have beaten the good routes for all of the characters, I have not yet played through the bad routes. I'm sure I'll play through them eventually, and will amend my review accordingly if needed.


The protagonist:

Heejung Kim, our leading lady, is an incredibly relatable character. Ever since her parents divorced, she has struggled to meet her mother's expectations. In doing so, Heejung has lost her sense of self. What does she want to do with her life? What kind of person does she want to be? As the game progresses, Heejung finds those answers.

While the game does not explicitly call the relationship between Heejung and her mother abusive, the characters of Dandelion universally acknowledge that Heejung's mother's behavior is unacceptable. No one ever attempts to encourage Heejung to make amends with her mother; no one ever makes excuses for her mother's behavior (e.g., "she just wants the best for you!"), either. That definitely won brownie points with me.

While Heejung's characterization is fairly consistent across all routes, there are some routes where her growth as a character is absolutely outstanding. If you like lots of character development in your protagonists, I highly recommend that you start with the Jieun route. 


The love interests: 

Before I bought the game, a friend warned me that the bunny routes were all much better than the cat routes. After clearing through all the good endings, I absolutely agree. The interaction between the bunny characters and Heejung were mostly positive; those relationships -- for the most part -- involved mutual support and care and respect.

Unfortunately, the same can not be said for the cat routes.

While the game did a fabulous job of addressing familial abuse, some of the romantic relationships on the game were abusive. While I don't plan on addressing those issues in every route, there is one love interest where the abuse is especially prevelant; that's the fan favorite, Jisoo's route.

During his route, he does the following:

-follows Heejung without her knowledge
-tells Heejung she can't be friends with any other men
-assumes that Heejung secretly has a boyfriend when he discovers Heejung crying about her mother and then retaliates by /pining her down/ and demanding to know why she lied to him about her relationship status
-repeatedly drags Heejung off by the wrist and holds her down against her will/protests  

Unlike the relationship between Heejung and her mother, the game fails to acknowledge that this behavior is abusive; disappointingly, it's even romanticizied. 

All of the bunny routes managed to make up for extremely unhealthy relationships that Heejae had with Jisoo and, to a lesser degree, Jiyeon. If you value healthy relationships, you'll enjoy any of the bunny routes.  If I had to recommend one, though, it'd definitely be Jihae's route.


Final Thoughts:

Dandelion - Wishes brought to you - is your standard otome game. You play a female protagonist, you fall in love, and Things Happen. While the story itself doesn't bring anything new to the table, it's (most of) the characters, the character development, and the way the game thoughtfully and respectfully address familial abuse that make Dandelion a stand-out title for me. Highly recommended.

Final ranking: 4/5

12663504.review:
Do I recommend this game? A million times yes! This is definitely worth the price if you're willing to splurge a little on a dating sim/otome game.

Characters and Story: 9.5/10
The personalities of each character as well as their corresponding backstories touched me deeply and made me cry every time. Jisoo and Jieun's especially. Story is tied into my rating for the characters because they are practically inseparable. The stories paired up with the personalities of the cast clearly define who they are and turn them into a wonderful group of characters that you grow incredibly attached to. Heejung's backstory is painfully relateable to the point that you just naturally sympathize or empathize with her. Each one of the guys also has a way of making their way into your heart as you try to understand and comfort them through the player character, Heejung. Those 29 hours were very much well spent considering how the range of emotions I went through as I played through each story. If I could go into detail about how I felt about each story individually, then we'd be here forever (and you'd have the whole game spoiled for you). My only problem in this section would just be very minor translation mistakes. It's played upon quite a bit for Jiyeon, but at times, the mistakes are a little obvious and out of place (especially at times where there is a tiny inconsistency with the name being said and the name being read). Fortunately, they don't badly interfere with the storyline, so I have no complaints.

Music+Voice Acting: 9.5/10
Once again, the soundtrack for this game is amazing and calming as well. It helped me relax during this stressful time (since I was in the middle of midterms not too long ago) and I truly wish I could get the soundtrack if it were being sold. Also, my reasoning for giving this a 9.5 would simply be due to the fact that the drastic changes between an intense situation and a regular day were a bit too quick for me. It's not exactly bad, but I guess I didn't have time to calm my heart after crying for a little while. I do like that the music fit the situations in the storyline very nicely though which truly added to the experience. As for the voice acting, I may not know much Korean (other than stuff from manhwa and K-pop which isn't a lot obviously), but I loved that the message, despite being in a completely different language, was still getting through. There is so much heart in their voices that it almost felt like you were Heejung and the guys were all talking to you.

Overall: 9.5/10
Definitely buy this if you have the money. You won't be disappointed in the least. There is a bit of stat raising which can be tedious at times (as they are in many otome games/dating sims), but the effort put into it goes a long way once you get to truly delve into this beautiful piece of work. Will I continue to play this after finishing the game? I already am. If you have the time (since this does take a good 3-4 hours per route not counting the common route bad ending) and the money, I suggest you buy this game if it interests you even the tiniest bit. You will not be sorry.

Oh. But on the downside, internet connection is a must. Be careful playing this in places with unstable wifi (like I did).

12663098.review: Probably the most wonderful and addicting game I have ever played. I poured 37 hours in 1 weekend into this game to finish every story and loved every second of it. I laughed, cried, and felt the emotion of the wonderful writing and each characters individual personality. Beautiful artwork, wonderful music, and a gripping story that is worth every penny.

12660901.review:
Dandelion - Wishes brought to you - is a stats-raising visual novel/point-and-click romance game that is, at its core, the story of Heejung, a 21-year-old university student in her last year, who feels like she has no direction in her life, suffers from low self-worth and thinks that she can amount to no more than being a failure. It's also a story about how she changes for the better after having five pets thrown into her lap out of nowhere and deciding to adopt them. It's also about the strange origin of said five pets (three rabbits and two cats) and the mysterious pact they made with an individual known as The Wizard to win a "game" he's arranged them to play that involves Heejung's unwitting participation...

And, of course, it's a story in which the player, depending on whose affection they raise the most, can help Heejung develop a romantic relationship with one of her five pets after they turn human.

GAMEPLAY: The way Dandelion is structured is that each love interest has a route and their own plot, meaning that each character has different conditions needed to get their official good ending. The similarities between these routes is that they all need to have their affection maxed out (get all of their hearts!), their necessary stats need to reach a specific level before the end of the game and the player needs to collect 30 stamps of the character they're pursuing. There are five stats to keep an eye on in all: Femininity, Beauty, Art Skill, Stress and Pressure. The first three cap at level 20, whereas the last two you will want to make sure the gauge never fills up else you will end up with a non-standard game over. In addition to these, there is also the heart gauge that once filled allows you to unlock new actions or to diminish the effects of stress or pressure.

Stats can be raised by performing an action, such as watching the education channel by clicking the TV in the living room to lower pressure and raise art, or by going out with a character and choosing to not look around. You can go out with a character in both their pet and human form during the weekend or you can choose to go to work (and receive $40) or stay home. Choosing to go out during a weekday gives the options of shopping at either the item shop or bookstore or to go to work (for $10). Keeping an eye on Heejung's wallet is important since the items or books that can be bought can be used to either boost her stats (or diminish the effects of stress and pressure) or be given as gifts to the character the player is pursuing. Each character has different preferences for gifts so keep an eye out for that!

*A word of advice!* Prioritize buying the eye medicine, which costs 200$. This is important since it allows the player to have more luck in finding useful items during the Look Around option during dates, which means better odds of finding stamps, stat-raising items or gifts.

Which leads me to detailing the specifics of dates! By choosing to go out with a love interest during the weekend, Heejung will get the option between choosing a stat raising action at the location of choice or of looking around. This is a fun little activity where you will be offered a bunch of random objects littered all over the background and you get to pick up three of them! Alternatively, you can quit the "investigation" at any time. Either way, the date ends and the game moves on to the next day.

Finally, there's raising a love interest's affection. This can be done either by taking them on dates, as explained above, or by finding them somewhere in the house and choosing the action where they're hanging around and successfully performing an action they enjoy. (For example, Jisoo frequently hangs around the fridge.) Gifts can only be given to a love interest after they turn human. An affection-raising action has been successfully performed if a yellow or pink heart appears; blue hearts or the spikey black circle signify a failed action and WILL reduce affection points.

***QUICK-SAVE BEFORE TRYING TO RAISE AFFECTIONS OR LOOKING AROUND DURING DATES*** There is no penalty for quick-loading several times and it will save you a lot of grief! You have about an in-game year to work on stats, so no need to stress, but better not to waste chances!

But enough about gameplay! LET US DISCUSS PLOT, PROTAGONIST AND LOVE INTERESTS.

As mentioned before, the game is told through Heejung's eyes as she struggles to get good grades in university for a job she doesn't want for a future she has no clear vision of. She's rather depressed and is questioning why she's working so hard for something she doesn't find rewarding, when one night, a mysterious individual bestows upon her the gift of suddenly finding herself to be a pet owner of three rabbits and two cats. Needless to say, when she wakes up to find a basket filled with five strange animals in her room, she initially freaks out, but over the course of the day (and week) she decides to take care of them, and afterwards becomes incredibly grateful for their presence in her life.

Heejung, in my opinion, is a huge success of a protagonist. She's incredibly relatable, especially in this day and age when our generation is struggling to find work and pay and meaning in our lives. It's incredibly up-lifting to see Heejung change from being monotone and hopeless to finding time to sit back and relax and enjoy the world around her, not to mention it gives you a warm, happy feeling to see her getting attached to her newfound family. Her backstory is also incredibly real for many of us, and though I won't spoil it, I think that helps give players someone tangible to connect with.

That, and it's nice to not play a high school student for once, especially when you've graduated a while back already and are struggling with the realities and responsibilities of Being An Adult.

The five love interests that the player can have Heejung hook up with are as follow: Jisoo, the black cat; Jiyeon, the orange cat; Jihae, the silver rabbit; Jieun, the small white rabbit; and Jiwoo, the spotted rabbit. They all have their own personalities and struggles to deal with (all of them heavy in spoilers so I won't go in detail here), each with their own appeals and possible deal breakers.

Jisoo, for example, is always looking out for Heejung and cares deeply about her well-being, but he's also the jealous and possessive type. Jiyeon is sweet and caring but his particular deal-breaker is a spoiler, so I'll just advise people to be careful with that one, cute though his ears may be. Jiwoo is hilarious because he reads romance novels seriously and is also just an all around hilariously arrogant and superior-than-thou type of guy, but those exact same traits might not cut it for others who aren't impressed with people who act like a jerkwad towards the protagonist. (To be clear, Jiwoo is a tsundere: Harsh on the outside, sweet and loving on the inside. It requires work to reach that soft side to him, but for many it may be more than worth it. Or not.) Jihae is nothing if not polite and courteous and forever attentionate towards Heejung, but he might also come off as boring and flat. And finally, Jieun is PRECIOUS CUTIEPIE LITTLE BABY RABBIT LET ME PET YOUR HEAD, but, uh, he's. Kind of young. His route is pretty PG, though, but that might still break it for many.

All in all, each route adds more to the story and reveals aspects of their origin as the story progresses, making it worthwhile to play every route to gain access to the true ending. The bad endings are also worth gunning for, if only to complete the gallery and memory in the extras, but I suggest playing them last.

Dandelion is a fascinating story that probably hits close to home for many with supernatural elements thrown in. I strongly suggest it for anyone who likes good plots, quirky but believable characters and a realistic portrayal of how stressful but varied life and relationships can be.

12660275.review:
I bought this game a few months after it first came out and am thrilled that it is getting the attention it deserves on Steam! I knew very little of this game before I bought it and was blow away by it.

The story deals with relatable, realistic problems; though there are some cliché elements. The story is completely character-driven, which is something I like. The narration is well done, though there are typos. There are five routes plus one Bad End for four of the routes, making a total of nine times you’ll have to play the game at least in order to complete everything. However if you mess up and don’t get enough stamps to unlock some of the extras, you may find yourself playing routes over. The good thing about this game is that it doesn’t take itself too seriously, yet can still make you sympathetic towards the characters.

The art work is fantastic. The artist did a great job at keeping a theme with the coloring and style. There is a background in almost all the CGs –the ones that don’t seem fine without. Only critic is that some CGs would have looked better if drawn from a different angle.

The background music does a good job at music setting the mood. I liked the soundtrack, however if you don’t you can simply set the BGM to off and still hear the characters beautiful voices. The voice actors are what bring the characters to life. All the voice actors are talented and display their characters perfectly.

Each character has a different backstory and character development that is believable and well-written.

Heejung makes a great main character because she is someone easy to relate to or at least one the player will be able to sympathize with. Cheritz did the right thing by not making her a blank-insert for the player. It’s better to have a relatable character than an insert for a story so character-driven. 

I have mixed feelings for Jisoo; I liked him in every route but his own. He is a “big-brother” type character. I have a similar opinion of Jihae; I liked him, but hated his route. Jiyeon was my least favorite; I found him to be rather selfish, didn’t enjoy his route either. Jiwoo was, to my surprise, my second favorite; he’s silly but also serious at times. I think he was the one best suited for Heejung. Jieun was my favorite; his route is the happiest one in my opinion.

For the other characters there is not much to say: The wizard makes an interesting sort of “villain.” I can’t say more without spoilers. Other minor characters, such as classmates and Heejung’s mother, serve their purpose.

Lastly there are a few things that should be mentioned: I’d recommend playing the demo first. It is a stat-based game, which I love but I know other otome gamers despise. Everyone has personal opinions, so you may hate or love most of the characters. Many people complain about the price of the game, however it is long and you are likely to replay it and it is nowhere near some of the prices of otome games from Japan. I enjoyed this game to its fullest and would/have recommend(ed) it.

12659196.review: Amazing artwork, lovely backstories interesting all the way through

12652336.review:
FYI: The reason my play hours is coming up as so little on steam is because I purchased the game directly from the Cheritz website right when it was released (back in November 2013) and played the whole game then. 

Don't let the initial synopsis fool you into thinking this will be a "fun silly game where you date animals". Sure Dandelion can be fun to play, but it's also SO much more than that. Dandelion's an immersive story that feels like it’s from another world. Yet, at the same time, it’s incredibly realistic. It addresses many themes such as self-worth, acceptance and sacrifice. Cheritz handles these themes with utmost care and it delivers to the audience.

ART:
The art is absolutely stunning. The colours are bright and vibrant. The characters all stand out and are very diverse in their appearances. I must admit, the visuals were the first thing that caught my attention. Both the sprites and CGs were very well done. 

STAT RAISING:
While at first, the stat raising in the game was fun and cute. Over time, it became repetitive and tiring to do for all the routes. Although, the pain of it all will be worth it for the characters and story. 

VOICE ACTING:
All the voice actors portrayed each character amazingly. They displayed a wide variety of emotions for every scene. I really felt the character’s personalities shone through their voices. I also really liked how Heejung was voiced too. 

MUSIC:
I really have to praise Cheritz on their music. The different character songs suit their respective characters and some made me laugh too.

CHARACTERS:
Heejung was a fantastic heroine. She is kind and caring, but has a teasing snarky side to her at the same time. I also really liked how relateable she was. It's nice to see how she develops throughout the game and how she comes to terms with her inner battles.

Each guy was vastly different from each other and I ended up falling in love with them all. Though, I must admit, Jiwoo ended up being my personal bias from the game. The interactions between the guys themselves was very fun to watch as well.

OVERALL:
Dandelion is a wonderful visual novel and I highly recommend it.

12652192.review:
Dandelion covers the story of Heejung who is a very studious young adult lady who spends most of her time attempting to become the ideal well-rounded student... but it's not what she really wants. She's pulled ahead by the invisible guide that her strict mom has set for her in life, but if you asked her what she wanted herself she wouldn't know what to say.
 
To an otome game regular, I thought she was a refreshing heroine who is quite relatable and strongly written, which can be a rarity in otome games sometimes. Her troubles form an important part of the story and I found it interesting how she ended bonding with the datable cast and changing along with them.

Not everything in Dandelion is played straight and all the guys have hidden secrets for you to discover throughout the game, which adds an interesting dimension to what may seem like a silly stat-raising game where you date animal boys. That being said, the story is fairly well-written in terms of depth of character, but keep in mind that this is a game meant for dating pretty boys at heart. You may not find this game to be entertaining if you don't like said pretty boys. Ahem.

Anyway, it's difficult to explain the charms of the game without spoiling the story, so I'll try summarizing briefly the different points:

♡ Charming and non-intrusive BGM
♡ Attractive and stylish art
♡ The translation is surprisingly good, though the prose may not be everyone's cup of tea
♡ Solid game design and system lacking bugs
♡ Relatable conflict and emotional character developments
♡ Full voice acting (heroine included!)

What you may find to be drawbacks, however, are:

X Prose not as strong as, say, an original English visual novel [i](but don't let that fool you, it's not like it's unreadable, but don't expect a flawless example of the height in literature)[/i]
X There is some awkward anatomy in the art, but I wouldn't say it's overwhelming and it's generally fairly solid.
X Long sessions of stat-raising with very little to break the melancholy once you've satisfied the stat requirements.
	[i]---(The stat-raising system can be repetitive after a while but it is fully functional. I think this may be preferable to those who dislike the long sessions of reading a straight visual novel may require or those who are new to the genre altogether.
Even if you dislike the stat-raising system, I'd say it's worth trucking through anyway if you would like the story. Keep in mind that the story has more meat on it than you may glean from the description provided, but  you can scratch the surface by playing the demo. I think that will provide you with at least the bare bones to determine if trudging through the stat-raising system to enjoy the story is worth it or not for you.)[/i]
X Unexpected character developments you may not be pleased with [i](never without proper justification, though)[/i]
X It's very easy to get lost without a walkthrough, though it is possible to get through if you're willing to make mistakes [i](which will sacrifice you much time unless you remember to create individual saves often)[/i].

I'd recommend this game to those who will form an attachment to the characters because this is one of the game's strengths, those who can enjoy stories that aren't all sunshine and don't feel that stories that will not provide full  closure are weaker for it.
	[i]---(Cheritz has always been ambiguous but I don't consider it to be a weakness. Their strength lies in the characters and their relatable conflicts and not the clean tying of knots for a satisfying ending, so to speak.)[/i]

If you're none of these, I can't really guarantee your full enjoyment of the game. In my own opinion, the game had many lovely moments though I couldn't come to like every character. Cheritz didn't fail to make it generally clear why they were the way they were, however. I strongly suggest playing the demo to have a taste of the stat-raising system because it really is a large part of the game and  the padding to express the passage of time. If you can't stand it, it will be hard to play because it's an unavoidable area. On the other hand, I know many who chose to play despite disliking stat-raising, myself being one of them. I found going through the stat-raising I usually abhor to read the story to be worth it in the end. 

Cheers.

12651154.review:
Dandelion is one of my favorite otome games. You play as Heejung, a college student who's dissatisfied with her daily routine and is trying to find her place in life. This routine is completely disrupted when two cats and three rabbits are mysteriously left in her home. Heejung slowly warms up to her new pets, who make her happy for the first time a long while. But lo and behold, Heejung is shocked to come home one day to find her pets have turned into humans! On top of their strange transformation, Heejung keep hearing mention of a "game" set up by an enigmatic Wizard. Who will be the winner?

Heejung, the heroine of the game, is one of the standout characters of this game. In many other otome games, the main character is usually bland so the player is able to self-insert themselves into the story. That’s not the case with Heejung; she’s a fully realized character with her own fears and goals for the future. Her constant worry about needing to be the best to please her overbearing mother is something that really struck a chord with me. 

The 5 main guys are all very likeable in their own ways (although I will admit the jealously streak that one character showed throughout his route annoyed me.) Not everyone is who they appear to be on the surface, and as Heejung gets close to each boy, you begin to unravel their past and true personalities. 

The gameplay includes raising stats in Femininity, Beauty, and Art Skills by performing a number of different tasks around Heejung’s apartment and raising affection with her beau. Raising the stats can get tedious at times, but there’s enough variety in activities that it never truly gets boring.

The art in this game is wonderful; each CG was a treat. The in-game music was nothing to write home about, but it gets the job done. (I really like the Wizard's theme a lot though.) The opening song is also probably my favorite opening of any visual novel I've played.

As of writing this review, I’ve completed 4 of the 5 routes in the game. (I’m saving Jiwoo for last because I know he’s going to be my favorite <3). Each route tugs at your heart strings, and the endings are bittersweet. When a game gets you so invested that you cry, you know it’s doing its job right. 

So in closing, I’d highly recommended this game for someone looking for a good story with lovable characters. Here’s hoping that Cheritz’s other game, Nameless, is also Greenlight on Steam! :)

12648739.review:
[I would like to note that this review is based on the original version of Dandelion from Cheritz’s shop, which is why I only have a few hours of gameplay on Steam]

Dandelion – Wishes brought to you is a visual novel otome game brought to us by the Korean company, Cheritz. In the English community, otomes are not an extremely popular subgenre. It’s fairly common for companies not to bother with an official translation of their game, and the ones that we do get are often games of fairly subpar quality, obviously meant to try and make the player pay as much as possible for things such as energy points. I had been hoping for something better, however, and after hearing about Dandelion from some friends soon after it’s release, I purchased the game with high hopes. Did it live up to my standards?
The short answer is: It most certainly did, for many reasons.

Story: Heejung is a young adult attending college. She has a past of being emotionally abused by her mother, which has led her to be depressed and constantly in a state where she feels stressed and pressured by the expectations she feels like she must live up to. Things begin to change when one day, she discovers a basket of animals, two cats and three rabbits, has somehow been left in her room. After some consideration, Heejung decides to raise these animals, and to her surprise, after a while, she discovers they have all turned into human boys!

The plot seems silly at first glance when you consider the idea of “dating pets,” but I was easily drawn into the game’s world. It sets up many questions about why exactly these animals were left to Heejung, where they come from, and their pasts. No character is as simple on the surface as you may wish to assume, and everyone is developed very well in their routes. I found everyone to be sympathetic on some level in a unique way. The characters all have very distinct personalities as well, and stand out from one another.

I was also impressed by the protagonist, Heejung. I believe Cheritz has written a very realistic and believable depiction of depression in her character. As someone who has dealt with these issues myself, I found her extremely relatable and she was a character I was always happy to see become more happy and confident over the course of the game. Some people accuse otome protagonists of being boring, but I personally do not believe that is the case with Heejung.


Gameplay: Dandelion stands out a bit from other visual novels in that it has a different sort of mechanic from what you normally expect of a visual novel dating sim. You spend a fair amount of the game simply managing Heejung’s day to day life by choosing activities for her to partake in during the day. Depending on what you choose to do, different stats of hers will either increase or decrease. Not being careful with your stats can lead to a game over. And depending on what you decide to do, you can run into one of the boys and begin building affection points with them. Not paying attention to your affection points can also lead to a bad ending. This is quite different from the typical dating sim, where you normally just sit through scenes and choose an option every now and then for dialogue. I found this style of gameplay a refreshing change of pace and an interesting difference.

The only real problem I have is that every now and then you can find typos in the dialogue, but luckily they’re actually fairly easy to miss if you’re not paying a ton of attention and don’t normally affect the flow of a sentence. I do, however, think that it may be beneficial in the future for Cheritz to have a native English speaker help proofread the script.


Art: Like I mentioned above, I’ve played a lot of subpar otomes. In a lot of them, the art isn’t too great, and is often very awkward looking in regards to anatomy. I was extremely relieved to find that the art in Dandelion, which is all originally drawn for the game, is nothing short of beautiful.

The anatomy seems quite fine to me, as there was nothing that jumped out to me in any of the character sprites or CGs that looked off at all.

The colors are actually one of my favorite parts of the art. The palette is very bright and colorful, which matches the game’s tone extremely well. The brightness however, isn’t overwhelming at all, and all the colors used mix together quite well for a very pleasant arrangement.
The backgrounds used are also quite well drawn. Perspective appears to be quite on point, and they are all quite detailed and well-drawn.


Music: The music in the game is quite catchy, but I never found it distracting. Every piece used fits the mood of the scene well. I also enjoyed both the opening and ending themes used quite a bit. While there wasn’t any music I considered particularly stand out or felt I immediately had to have on my ipod, it was all enjoyable and certainly not bad at all.


Overall: If you’re searching for an otome game of decent quality, with good art, story, music, and characters, this is it. Dandelion is sure to be an enjoyable experience for anyone who enjoys these kinds of games, and I would very quickly recommend it to anyone who is interested. Of course, I cannot guarantee it is for everyone, as anyone who is looking for something more “manly” or with more intense gameplay won’t find that here, but it’s really quite obvious that isn’t who Cheritz is interested in pleasing. Their slogan, “Sweet Solutions for Female Gamers” shows exactly what they’re trying to accomplish, and I’d say Dandelion certainly lives up to that. You’re sure to be entertained by this sweet and fun game.

12645026.review:
여성 유저에게 맞춰진 게임이라고 할 수 있는 게임  덴더라이언 - 너에게 부는 바람 이다.
육성이라는 점에 있어서 어렵게 느껴지거나 또는 루즈하게 느껴질지 모른다.
하지만 게임을 하다면서 숨겨진 복선과 흑막... 그리고 가장 중요한 연애스토리!!
때문에 수박의 겉핥기 식으로 대충 해보고 게임을 하는 것보단 끝까지 해본다면 이 게임에서 나오는 대사 하나하나가 전부 복선이라는 걸 느끼게 될 것이다.
굳이 싫었던 점을 뽑자면 엔딩. 게임상 스토리적으로 어울리는 엔딩이나 연애 게임이라는 점에선 조금 어울리지 않을 수도 있는 엔딩이라는 점.

12644373.review:
[b]Dandelion – Wishes brought to you[/b] is a reverse harem (or „otome“) visual novel/dating sim. Which means you play as a girl (named Heejung), and can choose on of several attractive males as your partner – yes, males, because the men in Heejung’s life start out as animals. Or, if you like, as trans-dimensional animal-men, who keep their fluffy ears even as humans.

[b]Gameplay[/b]

Dandelion is not a pure visual novel and has a decent amount of stat management. You have to raise three positive stats through different activities while avoiding to max out two negative stats, and raise affection with your chosen partner. There is also a hidden-item mini game, which unlocks additional pictures of the characters.
Sadly, Dandelion once again demonstrats why I prefer pure visual novels to stat-raising games. Stat-raising is semi-interesting in the first playthrough when you still figure things out and experiment, but gets more and more repetitive on subsequent playthroughs. And in otome games, you will very likely play through each character’s route, which makes about five playthoughs in Dandelion – more, if you don’t get the best endings on your first try.
A New Game+ feature would be a very nice addition and save you from clicking through the same fluff text again and again and again.
Also, let’s be honest here, stat-raising (and the hidden-item minigame) just ends in reloading until you get exactly the character interaction you wanted or find the item you were looking for. And that’s rather boring.

[b]Storyline[/b]

You play as Heejung, a stressed and lonely university student with an extremely overbearing mother. One day, a basket full of animals – two cats and three rabbits – myteriously appears in her room. Said animals soon turn into attractive men with cute ears and a lot of baggage, from the butler-like angora rabbit to the bad boy black cat.
And let’s not forget that Heejung herself has a lot of baggage. Actually, Heejung’s anxieties were a big draw for me. She feels much more like a realized character than most blank slate otome protagonists. 
Heejung grows as a character in each route, and even better, the male characters’ arcs mirror Heejung’s own development, which is really cool. It’s really satisfying when both parties change and grow.
Prepare for many a tear-jerking moment along each route – and for bitter-sweet endings.

As a warning: There is some problematic stuff in some of the romances, like physical violence and one character strays dangerously close to a shotacon (an absolute no-go for me).

[b]Artwork[/b]

Certainly one of the game’s high points. Each and every one of the characters looks gorgeous both ingame and in CGs and has a lot of different facial reactions – including cute ear movements. Special mention to Jisoo’s drooping ears when he sulks and Jieun’s surprised expression when you wear your facial mask…

[b]Conclusion[/b]

Do I recommend the game? Absolutely. The gameplay might not be the most fascinating, but both storyline and artwork make up for it – steam says I played for about 40 hours, which I guess speaks for itself.

12635322.review:

12628659.review: I usually wait until games are on sale to buy them. But this one I decided to get for the full price and I honestly feel like it was worth it. It is hard to get the perfect endings, which means a lot of time yelling at yourself and trying to figure out what you did wrong. So far I have only been able to get one romance, but it was worth it. 12627443.review:
Hello everyone!  This is my first time putting together a review, so bear with me.  I'll be dividing this post into 5 sections:  Plot, Individual Characters, Technical Features/Gameplay, Sound, and Art.  This will be a spoiler-free review.  If anyone wishes for my thoughts with spoilers on anyone else, I’d be happy to post that as well.


PLOT
The overall plot is simply amazing.  I have to admit, I was preparing myself to be thrown into a ball of stereotypes and other redundant plot devices & themes.  Fortunately though, there are a bunch of surprises and twists, and the game does a good job of making use of the cliches it has, while avoiding many others.  Don’t let these lovely, cute-looking pets in the beginning of the game fool you - you’re in for some pain.    

INDIVIDUAL CHARACTERS
Jiyeon:  Unfortunately, his route felt incredibly short (due to plot reasons), and because of this, I did not have the desired period of time to become attached to his character.  Not only that, but many of his actions weren’t really...appealing.  At all.  Overall, I felt he was the person who should least be with Heejung.

Jieun:  I liked Jieun more than I thought I would.  At first, I had thought his plot was going down a cliche path, but it diverted from such and I’m very happy it did so.  The story in this route was unique, and there’s much more to him than meets the eye.  There was plenty of surprises for me, especially since I did this route before Jihae’s.  He goes though most character development, hands down.  As you might’ve guessed, you get to learn plenty about Jihae as well, which is why I actually suggest doing Jihae before Jieun if you would like to be surprised about his backstory.  Out of everyone, I felt that he was the healthiest for Heejung.

Jisoo:  I expected to love this gluttonous dork.  Surprisingly...he was in the middle for me, due to a quality of his that you’ll run into...that isn’t healthy.  What I like about his path the most though, is that I feel that Heejung's own path in life was most recognized here, and she probably had the most personal growth here.  His route felt much longer than the others, with my personal favorite set of CG’s (besides the Wizard’s of course) in the game.  It also had some great, unexpected twists, so it was definitely a good route nonetheless, just not the best.  His ending was definitely top-notch though.  I feel that out of everyone, Jisoo had the largest motivation for winning the game.  My big tip for his route is that femininity does not matter nearly as much as your art skill and beauty, so definitely focus on raising those two up the most.  

Jiwoo:  Being the biggest dork you encounter, this dude is hilarious.  It’s definitely a good route to play right in the middle of all the heaviness of the game.  This route had to be my personal favorite, and this ending was the only one that had me absolutely bawling.

Jihae: First and foremost, if you want to be surprised by his backstory, do not play Jieun’s route first.  Jieun’s route will reveal a lot about Jihae, so I recommend playing Jihae’s route before Jieun’s.  With that being said, this route was good.  Although I felt Heejung's comments about how beautiful he is and etc., quite redundant, eventually I got used to it because hey - he IS pretty hot.  He probably had some of the most beautiful CG’s as well.

Wizard:  I love this guy.  He’s just so interesting.  There’s really not much to say without completely spoiling his character, but personal story was probably my favorite - you won’t be disappointed.

Heejung:  The heroine is actually my favorite part of this game.  I feel that anyone that has ever attended school, basically almost everyone, can relate to her - myself included.  The feeling of loneliness, of wanting to change, or the desire to know what it is you want to do in life, many of us have such wishes.  Especially the feeling of having to satisfy everyone else, forgetting you, yourself in the process.  In addition, her reactions to her situation, I believe, are realistic.  I could write an entire essay on how much I love her character.

My recommended play order for each character would be Jiyeon > Jisoo > Jiwoo > Jihae > Jieun.  Although many people recommend doing Jieun first to get used to the gameplay mechanics, I believe that if you’re looking for gradual plot progression, his route is fantastic to leave last.
My personal rankings for each route are Jiyeon <<<<< Jisoo <<< Jihae < Jieun < Jiwoo.


TECHNICAL FEATURES/GAMEPLAY:
First and foremost, I must mention the sprites.  I personally love how their mouths move, and how they actually blink.  Just small tidbits like this bring much more life to each character.  In addition, other little things such as the dandelions floating around the title screen, the leaves during fall, snowflakes during winter, etc. were all beautiful as well.  Secondly, I'd like to address the stat-raising aspect.  While it's cute and fun at first, it quickly becomes quite redundant.  Had it not been so repetitive, it would have been much more enjoyable.  It almost feels as if stat-raising takes up more of a route than the actual plot.  Other then that, the gameplay is pretty much standard visual novel gameplay - simply clicking.  
The game possesses all the basic features you’d expect:  Auto, skip, CG gallery, etc.  In addition, (and I loved this) the game features a special section where you can use the stamps you find on the routes to unlock bonus art - basically some concept art of the character, and an image of them (presumably after each ending) as their future self, whether it be human or not.  I HIGHLY recommend you try and unlock these, as they are simply stunning.  AN IMPORTANT THING YOU MUST KNOW (that I sadly didn’t ;-;) is that every time you start a new route, you must start a new game, or else your stamps will not be there by the time you finished the route.  I’m one of those people that likes to make a save file right before the first choice (while you’re on the common route) and go from there for each route, but unfortunately if you want your stamps, don’t make the same mistake as me.  Another tip I’d like to add is that if you’re interested in looking for stamps, work EVERY weekend until you reach at least $1200, then buy at least 6 visual improvement medications, to get increased eyesight out of the way - trust me, if you don’t want to flip over a table, you’ll increase your eyesight to at least 8 so you don’t have keep quick-saving and loading on a date to find stamps.  


SOUND
The voice acting is wonderful, what else can I say?  And while most side characters wouldn't get voices or sprites, Cheritz put in the extra effort to include them as well - Heejung’s mom, Heejae, etc.  Even Heejung has a voice, and it’s rare for heroine’s to be voiced as well.  Extra props to Jiyeon’s voice actor, you’ll know why.


ART
The art in this game is simply gorgeous.  I think I stared at the title screen for a few solid minutes when I first purchased the game.  The chibi’s during the stat-raising activities are adorable.  The vibrant colors fit the hopeful, cheery atmosphere the game possesses.  In addition, the garments for each character are designed in amazing detail, respective to each of their positions in the society back in their world.  For example, while Jihae's clothing may appear fancy enough that he could be mistaken as a noble like Jiwoo, that is not the case:  The colors are more diluted, and it's much less bejeweled in comparison.  It is not too difficult to find a visual novel with good sprites, but most of the time, the CGs are disproportionate.  That is not the case with Dandelion.  Funnily enough, it's CGs are actually higher in quality overall, compared to its successor, Nameless, which had some wonky-looking images (beautiful but occasionally disproportionate).

12626961.review:
Dandelion is an Outrageous game! 
Outrageously and hysterically funny and surprisingly deep once you get into it!

You play as a senior student, Heejung Kim who has moved to Busan from her perfectionistic and nagging Mother.
She hopes to find her own path in life in this new town and is a great student, but not knowing what she truly wants from life and not having much self-esteem from her past, she keeps stressing about being the perfect girl and being pushed down from pressure of korean society and the insane ideals of her Mother. 
So much that she has frequent flasbacks and nightmares, this being her trauma. 

One fateful morning the meowing of a cat wakes her up.
Heejung lives alone, but now a basket of 5 animals is lying next to her bed! How did that happen? 
Who are these animals who occasionally seem to talk between themselves? 
Why do the animals you've taken care of as pets instead of sending to a shelter despite your stressful life suddenly transform to handsome men later on, but can't explain anything about this insanity? 

In order to find out, and in order to progress the story enough to reveal their humanforms and further, you as the player need to take action! You start out with 5 adoreable pets(2 Cats and 3 Rabbits). Even though they change from pets to a bunch of dudes(with animal ears), Heejung decides to let them stay on the condition that they wear hats or hoodies to hide their ears when necessary.
Build up relationship points by interacting with them in your apartment, and occasionally by bringing them out for walks/dates. How you respond to events also affects your relationships, and the status of Heejung herself ofcourse.

Your adoreable pets are as follows;

*Jihae - The Silver Rabbit
The beautiful, princely and mature one of the bunch, Heejung and Jihae seem to share an interest in art.
He takes much care and responsibilty over Jihae and is stunning enough to be a model.

*Jieun - The Pure White Rabbit
The (shouta)youngest of the bunch, a quiet, gentle and closest to (Eddie..)Jihae.
He loves apples to the point of being addicted and doesn't talk much at first, being very thoughtful.

*Jiwoo - The Spotted(Cow) Rabbit
From the start he isn't the most social one of the bunch, nor the politest one.
He is however perhaps the most intellectual one! Stuck-up and rude, but smart rabbit. Can you say Tsundere!

*Jisoo - The Black Cat
The badboy if you will. He seems rough at first, but clearly has a soft spot for food!
He also likes to tease Heejung, but doesn't mean any harm. Just being a playful cat afterall...

*Jiyeon - The Orange Cat
The adoreable sweetheart of the bunch, rarely seen without a big smile on his face.
He seems very pure and childish at first and even makes several small language mistakes.
A charming heartbreaker!

Try not to let stress or pressure take over completly, or you might end up collapsing like a squished pudding with Heejae, your classmate. He seems sweet and is certainly caring for you, but is sadly your BAD ENDING!
So focus that doki doki on your pets! (wow, that sounds slightly wrong..)

You'll quickly learn how quick save/load is your best friend through gameplay while balancing stress, pressure and raising ceratin stats for certain characters. Whenever you need to check your staus, wallet, items(some can raise stats) and relationship progress, just right click and well.. click status on the menu!

Once you progress through the story it's easy to fall inlove with the personalities of the characters, the CG artwork is neat and sets the mood, and learning their stories I find myself wanting to play more and more and get to know each character. My personal favourite so far is without a doubt Jihae, but that might quickly change within the other routes as I've been focusing on this rare silver rabbitman's route. 
I enjoy seeing how the story progresses in a steady pace of growing feelings from being awkward at first to eventually blooming a romance to adoreable CG artwork.
As for music, my opinion is mixed. Some of the looping music became quite annoying which made me hope for more variation(to my relief that the next season change had another loop), but some of the bgm was very enjoyable.
I think music-wise it is more of a preference thing. However, the User Interface was absolutely to my taste!
Well organized, easy and very practical to the game (quick save/load, how I love it!)

All in all I'd say Dandelion is absolutely a game worth playing if you enjoy rich stories with colourful characters, and the fate of the protagonist lying in your hands! Enjoy your harem <3

12621898.review:
This is easily one of the best games I have ever played - definitely worth the money. Each character has a unique and interesting personality, as well as a well developed back story. Not to mention, the story itself is really interesting. 

As far as replayability goes, this is a game that is easily replayed over and over. Each path has it's own collection of cutscenes, so it keeps the story fresh and there is a skip option so you can speed through scenes you've already seen. So far, I've completed the game twice with two different paths and I'm still excited to play again. This game is full of feels too. 

Mechanically, it plays well too. The inclusion of a quick save button is helpful in making sure you achieve the interactions and results that you're striving for. But there's also plenty of room to explore the details of the game so you can learn the best way to get what you want. Since most paths have both a good and bad ending, if you mess up, it's not a big deal. You can just replay and go for a different ending.

Some of the English translation is a little rough sometimes, but it's still understandable and doesn't take away from the quality of the game. Plus, the characters all have a voice actor that can be turned on or off - granted, they say the lines in Korean, but I think it's a nice touch to hear the emotion behind the lines. There's also a nice inclusion of CG and artwork for the different characters that you can look at and a couple that you can unlock for each character.

All in all, this is a wonderful game and I definitely recommend checking it out.

12621079.review:
Previously, I have already played the game before it was released into steam and honestly I wouldn’t mind playing this game over and over again. Here’s why: 

In terms of art, music, and story, I think this game has done a good job focusing on all these aspects.

The art is consistant, anatomy is fine, colors are bright and CGs are all different yet, suiting. Giving you a reason to collect them all. Character designs are also lovely and suit with their personality and voices nicely, with the animals having 2 types of clothes, the modern one and fantasy one is also a very good call.

The music is nice no matter where you're at, and it doesn't get annoying (IMO the best would be the opening and ending songs of course).

Now the story, were do I being? Originally when I saw the game I was expecting a thick headed happy-go-lucky kind of protagonist, but nope! Heejung (The protagonist) is not only smart, down to earth, and caring; she also carries in herself a short of dark past. The game is constantly giving out new surprises throughout the story, and is excellent at pulling heartstrings. I even found myself going through all the good and bad endings (Something I don't do if the stories/endings are too similar or predictable). I also love how most events also bring in some of the other characters in the game. Certain otome games(dating simulations/visual novels) tend to isolate the main character and the love interest, but in many routes, there's still interaction between them and the rest of the characters. 

Now for secrets and bonus content. Other than just the usual 'get cgs throughout the route', the game also includes an amusing minigame that allows you to collect stamps of a certain character and unlock a bonus cg and the concept sketches. Another thing I liked is that the actual ending is after the beautiful credits, and the fact the credits would show all the CGs previously seen for that route, making it worth watching~
 
The only one thing I didn't like much was that the bonus was 'voice only', meaning to say since I didn't understand korean (in case you didn't know the game is voice and originally was in korean) I didn't understand what they were saying.  However, for those that just enjoy hearing the voices of the characters, this is a perfect treat.

12605640.review:
[i]Dandelion[/i] is a visual novel in which you control a female protagonist, Heejung, and build stats to pursue one of five men, each of whom sport adorable cat or rabbit ears. The premise revolves around two cats and three rabbits mysteriously being brought into the protagonist's home, then taking on a human form. How did they find their way into Heejung's home? What is the "game" they keep talking about, and what is Heejung's role in it? These questions are answered throughout the game's multiple routes, encouraging replays until all are completed and all of the story's pieces come together. 
 
Heejung is a very likeable and relateable protagonist. Unlike the majority of dating sim protagonists, who lack personality and backstory for the sake of "immersion," Heejung has a life and personality all her own. Watching Heejung handle her conflicts, such as an overbearing mother and her uncertainty of what to do with her future, makes her an enjoyable and relateable character. 
 
[i]Dandelion[/i]'s dateable candidates offer a variety of personalities and backstories. They all feature a level of complexity that can only be experienced by playing their route. Their diverse plots and reasonings for participating in the "game" results in wanting to know these characters beyond their initial introductions. The stories pull at your heart, with just the right amount of silliness sprinkled in with the sincerity. Each route is a fair length, and the voice acting is stellar, bringing life to each of the characters in conjunction with their bright, animated portraits. 
 
Gameplay is simple point-and-click, doing various activities to raise your stats, and interacting with the men to boost their affinity for you. The Stats menu lets you know if your stats are high enough to keep going down the character's good route, and you are given ample time to raise them, making playthroughs fairly straightforward. 
 
Features such as Auto, Skip, and Quick Save/Load make replaying the game for different routes convenient. Once you have viewed a specific scene, it becomes available for re-viewing in the Memory menu, making revisiting a previously-finished character's route hassle-free. 
 
Ultimately, [i]Dandelion[/i] is a touching, memorable experience. The characters are all unique, interesting, and multi-facetd, with appealing designs and engrossing stories. Fun, emotional, and heartwarming, I highly recommend this title to any fan of the otome genre.

12571508.review:
Well, first off, I have to say this is an absolutely beautiful game. If you’re looking for a subpar dating sim, you will have to look elsewhere, because Dandelion is very well put-together and a blast to play. The graphics are very nice and the characters are interesting and adorable in different ways. The stories for the different boys are very cool to learn about over time and the mysterious voice from somewhere is, uh, very mysterious. Very [i]I-don’t-explain-anything-but-I-imply-that-there-is-a-huge-background-here-wink-wink-to-those-who-have-played-the-game-enough[/i]. So yeah, very mysterious to me. One of the only issues that I had with it was the typos that popped up sometimes, but overall the translation was well done. They did a very good job of maintaining the sweet, giving nature of Heejung while also revealing her struggles and discontent. She can almost seem too placid, but it is understandable, given her past, and as the game moves forward, she does show signs of a backbone as she comes in to her own (thanks, furry adorableness?), which I whole-heartedly approve of.

It takes some time to recognize the voices and names (very creative, Heejung…lots of J’s @_@) but once you do, it becomes very easy to know who is speaking during scenes that don’t show faces. The different colors help and the personalities are so unique from one another that it becomes clear pretty quickly. The stat system is very intensive if you want to buff them all out, but the options are cute and for some of the boys, it’s important to max out your stats as quickly as possible. Just think of it as primping and sketching your way to the top. I actually do enjoy the grind, because the little illustrations are cute and it’s nice to become beautiful just by taking a bath. Unfortunately there have been no side effects in real life.

The most important thing that you should keep in mind when playing this game is FOR THE LOVE OF ALL THAT IS FURRY AND CUTE DO [b]NOT[/b] TRY TO GAIN HEARTS FROM ALL OF THEM. You may think, ‘Oh that’d be nice to be friends with all of them! I’ll just hang out with everyone and become a more well-rounded person!’ That is the quickest path to a bad ending, except in a few special cases, which I'm sure you'll figure out after a couple of hours of playing. 

Yes. 

I was there.

 Let me lay out the scene for you:
There I was on a different guy’s route, when I thought I would go out on the weekend and have a nice, friendly lunch with Jiwoo, you know? Just two buds hanging out and becoming even better friends. Maybe he’d even stop calling me stupid one day! During lunch, he says something about me feeding him, and being the desperate-for-points-and-new-interactions player I am, I chose the ‘Open wiiiide” option, thinking it was a little weird, but hey, I don’t judge friendships. Then he goes and says something about not dating any other boys. And if I were really Heejung, I would have stopped in my tracks and wondered, ‘You think we’re dating?!?!’ But of course, I am not her, and the game just continued on, unmindful to the fact that it had just rocked my world. When I started the game, I thought that Heejung was very oblivious when it came to boys, which was cute but almost a little much. Now, I know the horrid truth. I am JUST as [b]oblivious[/b] and [b]stupid[/b] about boys as a main protagonist of a DATING simulator. TT_TT

Let’s just say there is one bad ending in particular which is more than a little traumatizing and I couldn’t stop thinking about it last night. On the bright side, they did an excellent job of unobtrusively sliding you into an abusive and very dangerous relationship, with you torn between thinking there is something very wrong, and thinking that it will turn out okay once he calms down. 

He didn’t calm down.

 I am still a bit emotionally scarred and I have been hesitant to play his good route (I just need some recovery time…). I recommend you get all the good endings before you try to get the bad endings for completeness—that way you’ll still be able to sleep at night without thinking someone’s going to be hovering over your bed. Following you to the bathroom…not letting you talk to people…scarring the actual player for real…or maybe that’s just me. But, what the heck, do whatever you like! [strike](It’s your funeral)[/strike]

On a completely random side note, I like to pretend that the silver-haired man in the city panoramic scene that pops up once in a while is actually the main protagonist from Persona 4 (just to spice up the scenery for me). Unfortunately, no matter how many times I click on him, he does not become a dateable furball of cuteness. But I can just imagine him as a large darker gray-haired rabbit, majestically lording over everyone in King’s Game. X3 He’d fit right in with Jieun and Jihae!

12533139.review:
*This review is based off of the version of Dandelion directly from dl.cheritz.com. This is why Steam only claims I have played this game for a few hours.*
Basic plot: 
A college student, Heejung, is living alone in her apartment. The influence of her overbearing mother forces Heejung to frequently second guess herself. To add onto her worries, Heejung wakes up one day to find a basket of five animals next to her bed. She questions where they came from but accepts them as her own after a week or so. Now she must take care of five animals and manage her college expenses. Things only get more complicated when they turn into humans.

The Gameplay: 
This game is classified as a visual novel but is more of a stat raising game with visual novel elements. The player must focus on raising their relationships with each of the available suitors while maintaining high femininity, art, and beauty. However, the stress and pressure levels must remain low. Doing activities such as going to work or taking a shower will change the stat levels. The key is to find a balance as to what activities raise the most stats while raising the stress and pressure levels as little as possible.

Each suitor has stats that they prefer. Some have lower standards, while other have higher standards. If the requirements are met within a certain period, usually 1-2 months, an event will occur. Unlike other visual novels where the player picks different options to make an event occur, the stat raising activates the event. When an event occurs, there are no text options to make. I felt that the stat raising element was a nice change from the other visual novels I have played. Having to watch my stats kept my interest and made it hard to stop playing the game.
There are even collectible stamps. When you get enough of them for each character, it unlocks bonus content.

The Characters:
I feel that the character development is one of the best parts of the game. The stat raising game play allows close interaction with each of the characters. The characters are confined to one house most of the time so the player is forced to interact with each. There are not a lot of events for each character, maybe seven or so. That means that whenever an event occurs, something important is bound to happen. I commend Cheritz for creating characters with faults. For most visual novels, the heroine seems to be either perfect while the options have faults or vice versa. In this game, both the heroine and the characters have problems. This, added together with the stat raising actions, gives the game a sense of relatability.

The Voice Acting: 
Each voice matched the characters perfectly. I have no complaints. The voice actors of the cats even meowed; that is dedication at its’ finest.

The Music: 
The background music often sounds like elevator music, but surprisingly, that is not a bad thing. The music matches the calmness of a house or a stroll around the park. As a whole, the soundtrack is very happy. There are only a few songs for perilous situations, the rest are very calming. I really liked the OP song as well.

The Art:
The artists for the game are absolutely amazing. I am assuming that the CG artist and the sprite artist are different people since the CG’s look different than the sprites. However, the CG’s still look beautiful. The backgrounds stay consistent from behind the sprite to the background of a CG in the same room. The interface is drawn to look like a notebook and has very cute flowers and drawings throughout.

Positive Aspects:
Here is a list of some of the best qualities of Dandelion.
-All of the characters have distinct personalities; none of the characters are alike.
-The art is consistent.
-The music matches the scene.
-Having to raise stats keeps the player engaged.
-Having the characters live together forces the characters to form relationships. These relationships are explored throughout each route, stay consistent, and add to character development.
-Players of both genders could enjoy the game.
-The main character is not a ‘wall flower’. 
-The main character develops alongside the suitors. Heejung changes for the better as the game progresses.
-The game has ‘collectibles’ that the player can hunt for on dates.
-The opening theme song is amazing.
-The primary bad endings made sense for each character given their personalities.

Bad Aspects: 
Here is a list of minor complaints.
-To get the best end for one of the characters, another character must like you a decent amount as well. The game fails to make this obvious. I was half way through the route before I realized I was on a bad path that I could not fix.
-There was no true route for Heejae. 
-One character is significantly harder to satisfy. Some people, like me, may do his route first and fail a lot. If you are like me, playing his route first makes the other routes extremely easy.
-It was never clearly stated that the game ends in  about a year. It only shows signs of ending a month before the game actually ends. For their first route, players will probably be scrambling at the end, reloading past saves just to raise their stats high enough by the end of the month.
-It is not always clear what option is considered the best on dates.
-Some of the character’s required stat levels did not make sense when you take their personality traits into account. (I cannot explain this further without spoiling anything).
-The translation had minimal errors; Jisoo’s route seemed to have the most errors and the ‘Special’ menu’s ‘back to title’ button was still in Korean. Otherwise, the translation was pretty good. 

Aspects that will be good to some but bad to others:
-Since the options are living with the player and are treated as pets in the beginning, it takes a while for any romance to start. 
-Events are caused by raising stats instead of dialogue options.
-All routes connect to each other in some way.
-All of the endings except for maybe one ended abruptly. The endings are left to interpretation.
-The ability to quick save at almost any time makes the game really easy to get collectibles and items to sell. This also makes it really easy to pick the proper responses on dates.
-The game focuses on character development as opposed to plot. 
-All of the plots are connected, so the player may be confused during their first play through.

Final Thoughts: 
I really enjoyed this game and would highly recommend it. All of the characters had distinct personalities and I liked the stat-raising. Sadly, I wound up playing the hardest route first, and then found out how to raise each stat really easily. This caused the rest of the routes to go by really slowly since my stats were already so high; I had nothing to do between events. However, this did allow me to get the collectible stamps with ease. I disagree with the people who feel that this game is difficult. The game takes time to get used to, but with the ability to quick save almost everywhere, learning what raises what and finding items on dates is really easy. Also, people complain that the stat raising gets monotonous; I disagree with that as well. Once you learn what to do, you can raise Heejung’s stats so fast that it does not feel monotonous for too long. After going through one route, raising Heejung’s stats becomes easier.

There is no clear order to play the routes in, but I would recommend one of two orders:
Play Jieun, then Jihae, then Jiwoo or Jiyeon, then Jisoo
Or
Play Jisoo, then Jiwoo or Jiyeon, then Jihae, then Jieun
Either way, make sure that either Jisoo or Jieun is first or last and that you play Jihae near when you play Jieun. As you can guess, their routes go together. I would recommend order two over order one if you want to go by story since Jieun’s route is completely different from every other route. However, if you want an easy play through, go with order one.

12517751.review:
This game is like playing the fic, "Take It or Leave It" in visual novel form, right up to the mysterious creeper who set the whole scenario up. 12435695.review:
At first I was a little leery of purchasing this game, especially with the stat system. I had played Spirited Heart and was sorely disappointed with the system and how I couldn't romance a guy AND try to aim for the goal that was set out for me. So when I saw that there was a demo to Dandelion I decided to give it a try. Before I knew it the demo was over and I desperatly wanted to know what was next.

That right there was a good sign that I would like the full version of the game. I didn't delay in purchasing it and pursuing Jihae (I did have to check a guide to make sure I was on the right track) and oh man. The feels. He was so sweet, kind, loving, and was a tiny bit jealous. The story line was good, I could relate to the heroine , the art and the music is FANTASTIC. And while raising your stats to try to woo your choice of bachelor you had a good chance in interacting with them if they were in the room. Yes, I had to quick save and quick load to get that to happen sometimes but the fact that I could was awesome.

What I mostly love about this game though was how much I really grew to care about Jihae. I was nearly as heartbroken as the Heroine towards the end of the story line (trying not to spoil the ending). I would highly recommend this to anyone who enjoys these kind of games. I *do* recommend checking the guide available on steam if you want a decent idea what you should do without any spoilers. Some of these bachelors are *tough* to get. All in all? *Great* game. 10/10!

12396942.review:
[b]Personal Opinion[/b] - I bought this game a couple years ago when it first came out in English, and I do not regret it. It's a visual novel with a lot of emotional pull. There is something about each of the routes you can play that will elicit some sort of emotion from you, and they're not always happy ones. This game will twist your heart into knots.

[b]Technical Aspects[/b] - In the original non-Steam version, there were a few typos in the English subtitles, but nothing that hinders comprehension or gameplay. Saving and reloading is easy, the menu easy to navigate. There is also a 'skip read text' option for those who hate re-reading text found in multiple routes. You can tweak how fast the text appears on your screen, and how fast it auto scrolls for those that choose that option.

[b]Gameplay[/b] - The stat raising you need to do for each route is a little confusing and monotonous, but there are plenty of handy guides online to help you figure out witch stats you need for which routes and how to raise them. [url=http://otomesweetheart.tumblr.com/post/37155401342/dandelion-tips-on-jisoos-good-ending]Like this[/url], which tell you things like you need to worry about your art stat the most with Jisoo and such. There are 'Bad Endings' in some of the routes. Whether you try to get them for completionists sake is up to you, though if you can handle disturbing scenes in your games you should, if for no other reason than to get all the CG's and to have a peak into the characters darker sides.

[b]Personal Rating[/b]  - 9/10: the monotanous stat raising and occasional typo detracts one star from an other wonderful game. =)

I also feel like there isn't truly much in the way of choices(besides picking one thing to do at home each day of the week and one thing on the weekends).

But overall: A really good game for those that like Visual Novels.

12393822.review:
Let's start with the few not so good things:
1. This game has typos (however, it is not all over the place and maybe if we ask Steam nicely enough, they'll fix it.)
2. It is a stat based game (I can see this being a potential turn off)
3. It costs 29.99 (however, it is cheaper than some other dating games, like the 70.00 stuff from Japan)

Now let's get on to the good stuff,
1. Hot guys.
2. Multiple different endings.
3. Actual plot.
4. Fairly deep characters.
5. Really hot guys.

Other stuff you might want to know:
